text:
We have problems with tomcat on a HP-UX11 system on which tomcat consumes more 
than 200 % cpu on a 5 cpu machine after several hours of running.

But the load of the tomcat is almost idle.

We do not use tomact with apache. It is serving static pages only.
creator: a.vanderende@chello.nl
remm@apache.org
text:
I have yet to witness a situation where Tomcat consumes CPU doing nothing.

A bug report should either include detailed information on how to reproduce it,
a ready to use test case, or at least enough information so that developers have
a good idea about where the problem comes from. You seem to assume that the
problem is obvious enough so that we ought to notice it (which is not the case).
In any case, you'll have to investigate the issue more (a starting point would
be to get a thread dump to get an overview of threads or portions of the code
which could be posing problems). If you need general support on Tomcat, please
try the tomcat-user mailing list.

creator: a.vanderende@chello.nl
text:
Then tell me how I can force a thread dump , if the command kill -3 or -4 does 
not kill the tomcat process!!!!!!

I was going to open a new bug, but this seems to describe my issue very well. 
Although not the same platform.

My issue is Tomcat consumes 100% cpu in idle state on a single processor 
machine. This is without making a single HTTP request to Tomcat. Basically I 
start Tomcat using startup.bat and then wait a few hours. Eventually it 
(java.exe) will start to consume 100% cpu. I have reproduced this on three 
different machines and I've been struggling with it for about a month now. I 
can reproduce this on a clean install of Tomcat with no added libraries and 
nothing but the default Contexts.

My Platform:
Tomcat 4.1.24
JDK 1.3.1_07
Windows 2000 SP3

I will be happy to try anything to assist in isolating the error, but I will 
need instructions on what to do.
creator: clayembry@yahoo.com
remm@apache.org
text:
I will resolve that report according to my previous comments. You can easily get
a view of threads which are running by using ctrl+break (on Windows). Do not
reopen that report unless you can provide conclusive information about a flaw in
Tomcat.
